title: Introduction
body:
In this module, we will look at three founding pillars of good analysis, each supported by the one before it.

A good quality piece of analysis is:

  • Reproducible
  • Auditable
  • Assured

title: Definition
body: Reproducible analysis: "the same analysis steps performed on the same dataset consistently produces the same result"

title: Example – statcheck
body:
Many scientific disciplines have gone through reproducibility or replication crises. Some of these concerns are due to difficulties in recreating experiments, but some of the blame lies with mathematical or manual error.

In 2015, the journal Behaviour Research Methods documented reporting errors in a sample of over 250,000 p-values. These p-values were taken from major psychology journals between 1985 and 2013. The study was carried out using the R package statcheck. This package allowed researchers to crawl through papers and find basic errors like rounding errors and misreported p-values.

The study concluded that “half of all published psychology papers … contained at least one p-value that was inconsistent with its test”. Most striking was that the errors weren’t entirely random: “most of the errors tipped the results in favour of statistical significance”. On top of this, “around 13 percent of the papers contained an error that could potentially change the paper’s conclusions”.  

The result of this is that trust in the scientific evidence was reduced. It became very hard to draw conclusions from a paper because there was a good chance it contained a mistake.

See the published article for more information.

title: Definition
body: Auditable analysis: "analysis and supporting evidence are available for scrutiny"

title: New Component Title
body:
If decisions are made based on our analysis, then that analysis should be available for scrutiny. This is particularly true when those decisions include the allocation of public funds. It is vital that we not only perform high quality analysis but are also seen to do so.

At any time, we should be able to answer:

  • Who made each decision?
  • When was each decision made?
  • What evidence was each decision based on?

Answering these questions gives decision makers and users greater trust in our work. They know the story of our analysis and why we made certain analytical choices. They know who is responsible for each part of the analysis, including the assurance.

title: Example – 2020 exam results
body:
In 2020, schools were closed in response to the coronavirus outbreak and public examinations did not take place. Statistical algorithms were developed to award grades in the absence of exams. When grades were released, “there was widespread public dissatisfaction centred on how the grades had been calculated and the impact on students’ lives”. 

The Office for Statistics Regulation (OSR) reviewed the processes and found that the teams and organisations involved “acted with honesty and integrity”. However, “public confidence was influenced by a number of factors”, including but not limited to:

  • “Transparency of the model and its limitations” – whilst the regulators “undertook activities to communicate information … full details around the methodology to be used were not published in advance”. This was due to a variety of reasons, including “short timescales for model development” and “a desire not to cause anxiety amongst students”.
  • “Use of external technical challenge in decisions about the models” – regulators drew on external expertise and carried out “extensive analysis”. Despite this, the OSR found that “the methods were not exposed to the widest possible audience of analytical and subject matter experts” and “a greater range of technical challenge may have supported greater consensus around the models”.

The OSR report’s key lessons for those developing statistical models are:

  • “Be open and trustworthy”
  • “Be rigorous and ensure quality throughout”
  • “Meet the need and provide public value”

In the context of auditability, this means “ensuring transparency about the aims of the model and the model itself”, “being open to and acting on feedback” and “establishing clear governance and accountability”.

For the full findings and recommendations, see the Office for Statistics Regulation report.

title: Definition
body: Assured analysis: "analysis has passed through a systematic process that established it as fit for purpose"

title: New Component Title
body: As well as being reproducible and auditable, analysis must also be fit for purpose. To prove this to ourselves and our stakeholders, we must put our analysis through a quality assurance (QA) process. The QA process should check if it was completed correctly and is appropriate evidence for decision making. The level of QA required should be proportional to the risks and importance of the decisions it is supporting. The best way of demonstrating assurance is through peer review.

title: Example – West Coast Main Line franchise
displayTitle: Example – West Coast Main Line franchise
body:
In 2012, the contract to operate the London to Glasgow rail line expired. Train operators competed for the new franchise, which was initially awarded to FirstGroup. However, the competition fell through after the previous operator launched a legal challenge.

Several bodies investigated and found that the process "was littered with basic errors". There were "fundamental errors" in how the model underpinning the decision was created and managed. Senior leaders "could not see all the information which might have enabled [them] to challenge the processes". Technical errors were not discovered or communicated effectively. In the end, the Department for Transport abandoned the franchise competition and paid £40 million in compensation. Sir Nicholas MacPherson was commissioned to write a report on the quality assurance of Government analytical models. Following this report, guidance for government analysts was published in the Aqua Book.

_items.title: Minimise manual steps
_items.body: We should minimise the number of manual steps in our pipelines. Manual processes include copy-paste, drag-drop and point-click actions. They are especially common when using spreadsheets or the graphical interfaces of software like SPSS. When we do a manual process the computer software converts it into code. We can cut out this intermediate step by creating our analysis using a programming language. Producing our analysis with code directly connects our inputs and outputs. It reduces the chance of human error and makes analysis easier to reproduce. It also decreases the risk of knowledge being lost when people move on. Implementing automated processes to make our analysis reproducible is one of the top goals of the Government Statistical Service (GSS) Quality Strategy.

_items.title: Maximise transparency
_items.body: Throughout the whole development and use of our pipelines, we should maximise transparency. This makes it easier for stakeholders and independent experts to scrutinise our work and ensure maximum value and impact. This is emphasised in the Service Standard, written by the Government Digital Service (GDS) to help teams to create and run great public services. Point 12 of the GDS Service Standard states that all new code should made open by default. In the small number of cases where this is not possible, justification should be given.

_items.title: Open-source software
_items.body: It is difficult to make our analysis transparent if our stakeholders cannot access the software needed to read and run the analysis. We should therefore use open-source software for our analysis. Open-source software also has the benefit of large user bases both inside and outside of government. These users communities are happy to share knowledge and support other users.

_items.title: Version control
_items.body: To enable auditability, we need a good system of version control. Our version control should record changes to the pipeline, who made them, when and why. Like our code, our version control should be open and accessible to our stakeholders.

_items.title: Embedded documentation
_items.body: Our pipelines should be well documented, and that documentation should be embedded in our code. This makes collaboration easier, as well as allowing for easier auditing and assurance. When documentation exists alongside the code, it is more likely to be kept up to date than if it is spread out across different systems. Having the documentation as part of the code means we have a single source of the truth.

_items.title: Automated quality assurance
_items.body: We should automate the aspects of quality assurance that are challenging for humans. This frees up time and makes it easier to keep a record of what QA has been performed. The purpose of this automation is not to get rid of analysts, but to allow analysts to focus on the QA that computers cannot easily do. For example, analysts are much better at ensuring that the analysis is fit for purpose.

title: New Component Title
body: These principles came together in the first “RAP” project. This project was a collaboration between the Department for Culture, Media and Sport (DCMS) and the Government Digital Service (GDS). In late 2016, these two organisations worked together to develop a new pipeline for the Economic Estimates for DCMS Sectors. They brought together techniques from reproducible research, software engineering and DevOps. They called the results a “reproducible analytical pipeline”. Since then, RAP has been adopted by teams across government. In the next module, we will see some tools that will help us apply these principles in our own teams.

title: New Component Title
body: When creating a Reproducible Analytical Pipeline, we should use an open-source programming language. The best programming language will vary from project to project, but R and Python are great choices for most types of data analysis. R has its strengths in statistics and data visualisation and is used widely for research in government and academia. Python is a more general programming language that is also commonly used for data engineering and web development. There is extensive training and community support for both languages inside and outside of government. The choice will usually depend on existing team knowledge and departmental preference.

title: New Component Title
body: Git is the most used software for version controlling code. Once installed and initiated, Git will track all changes to a project. It will also prompt users to add messages explaining why they made these changes. Git can be configured to prevent the sharing of sensitive information such as data and passwords.

title: New Component Title
body:
We cannot be sure that our code works without running it on realistic examples. Many analysts will be familiar with doing manual sense checks on their outputs. Treating analysis as software allows us to go one step further and turn these checks into formal tests. In their simplest form, software tests run a part of the pipeline on example data. They assert that the output data meets certain expectations. If these expectations are not met, an error will be raised. The analyst can then investigate what caused this error.

Modularising our code makes it much easier to check that it is working as expected. For each important or complex function, we should write at least one test. Low-level functions are known as units and this type of testing is called unit testing.

Other types of software testing also exist. These include:

  • Integration testing: tests that check that two or more units work together correctly
  • End-to-end testing: tests that assure that a complete pipeline as expected
  • User acceptance tests: tests where a pipeline user confirms their requirements are met.

title: New Component Title
body: Once we have a package with tests, we can introduce continuous integration (CI). CI allows us to automatically check that our package builds and all our tests pass, every time we make a change. Two examples of continuous integration software are Travis and GitHub Actions. In the following GitHub Actions example, GitHub checks our package and runs our tests every time we push changes.

title: New Component Title
body: We can set the pipeline to run automatically, for example at the same time every week, or whenever it detects updates to our data. We keep the human in the loop by raising warnings or errors when problems are detected. These can then be monitored, investigated, and corrected. Analysts are also required to interpret the results and provide insightful bespoke commentary.

title: New Component Title
body:
Traditionally, most public sector analysts have managed their projects using a Waterfall approach. Using Waterfall, projects are divided into distinct, sequential phases, for example:

  1. discovery and conceptualisation
  2. planning
  3. launch and execution
  4. performance and control
  5. decommissioning and closure.

Each phase must be completed and signed off before moving on to the next. The phases might be done by different people, or even by different teams.

title: Example
body:
1. Alex has an idea for a new experimental statistic. They identify potential stakeholders and set project goals. They then submit this initial concept to the leadership team.
  2. The leadership team like the initial concept and have asked Becky to manage the project. She first gathers stakeholder requirements. She then creates a plan, setting out the schedule and budget for the project. She also recruits a team of analysts.
  3. Charles is the senior analyst on the team for this project. He creates a technical design and his team work hard to create an end-to-end pipeline for the new statistic.
  4. Whilst Charles is building the pipeline, Becky monitors his progress. She makes sure he sticks to the plan and deadlines.
  5. Once the pipeline is finished, it is handed over to Dan in the Operations team. Becky produces a final report on the quality of the work and whether it was completed to budget and deadlines.

title: New Component Title
body:
There are several issues with this way of working:

  • Requirement gathering is completed early in the process. This requires stakeholders to be very clear on what they need from the beginning and not change their minds.
  • User researchers, developers and operational staff are deliberately separated. This is traditionally done so you only pay for the talent you need at any given time. However, this can mean that developers don’t understand user needs and operators don’t understand the pipelines they are running. 
  • Working software is only delivered at the end of the project. This is the first time the customer sees the software. If they are not happy with what is delivered, the whole process must be repeated.

When we are doing analysis in the public sector, requirements are not always clear. Policy officials may not be able to clearly define their technical requirements and the public need can change. Elected officials and the public should be able to audit our work at any time. Fortunately, there is an existing approach to managing software engineering projects that meets these aims...

_items.title: User Needs
_items.body:
When creating a RAP, we should identify our users early and focus on their needs. Agile requirements are often communicated in the form of User Stories. That is, an informal explanation of what a user needs to do and why, rather than a detailed specification of how to code a feature. These are commonly structured as follows:

“As a... I want to... so that...”

For example,  “As a DfT policy official, I want to understand the locations of traffic jams, so that I can allocate infrastructure funding.”.

We consider a story completed when the user need is met.

Unlike in Waterfall, in Agile we welcome changing requirements. This is because users refining their requirements will result in a better final product. It also puts less pressure on users to create highly specific descriptions before they have seen any tangible examples.

_items.title: Working Software
_items.body: In Agile, working software is considered the primary measure of success. This means that we don’t spend months creating detailed plans and documenting specifications. Instead, we prioritise early and continuous delivery of working software. With RAP, this means creating a runnable pipeline as soon as possible. We then iterate based on stakeholder requirements. Different teams work to different schedules, but we should ideally have a deliverable increment at least every couple of weeks.

_items.title: Teams
_items.body:
Agile acknowledges that the best outcomes come from self-organising teams. Agile teams build a strong relationship with their users and then work together to meet their users needs. Rather than day-to-day work being dictated by a manager, teams allocate tasks between themselves and hold each other to account.

Agile teams should be “cross-functional”. They should be made up of people from different disciplines, working towards a common goal. In Agile, these people are often referred to as “developers”, but that doesn’t just mean people who code. When producing a RAP, the team should have the skills to gather user requirements; design, implement and test the pipeline; and disseminate the results. Whilst these are all specialist skills, team members should be willing to expand their areas of expertise as required to remove blockers.

_items.title: Development
_items.body:
At every increment, we should be delivering technical excellence and good design. This can be encouraged by including acceptance criteria with each user story. For example, the acceptance criteria for a new pipeline feature might be:

  • Feature is written as functions with docstrings.
  • Unit tests have been written for each function and they all pass.
  • Code has been reviewed by at least one other member of the team.

Agile practitioners may use terms like “sprint” or “extreme programming” that sound exhausting, but teams should have a sustainable pace of development. Developers should be able to maintain their pace indefinitely without burning out.

Alongside regular delivery, our teams should also be regularly reflecting on their work. This means looking at the quality of our pipelines, but also how we are working as a team. Where we find places for improvement, we should adjust the way we work.

title: Agile frameworks
body:
Since 2001, several frameworks have gained popularity amongst Agile practitioners. These frameworks encourage and support people to adopt the principles of the Agile Manifesto. When working on a reproducible analytical pipeline, the two most popular frameworks are Scrum and Kanban.

The Scrum framework is structured around Sprints – fixed periods of time with set goals. At the end of each Sprint, the team should have a deliverable increment to share with key stakeholders. Working in this cycle of delivery and reflection allows teams members to get regular feedback from each other and their users, and instantly implement it in their work.

The Kanban framework is structured around the Kanban board. At its simplest, a Kanban board is a table with three columns: To Do, In Progress and Done. User stories are written up on cards that get moved through the columns as the work is completed. This allows for full transparency and real-time communication.

Both Scrum and Kanban can help us on our journey to an Agile way of working. When starting out, it can be helpful to choose one framework and try to implement it. Scrum works well for long term projects as it provides a clear structure and roles. Kanban is a great choice for projects with lots of incoming requests that vary in priority and size. Whatever framework we end up using, our team should always to be looking to improve, and focusing on user needs and delivering a quality reproducible analytical pipeline.

title: Starting to RAP
body:
When introducing RAP into our projects, the best approach is:

  • Start small and grow, for example use one element of RAP or RAP one part of the pipeline. This will help show value early on.
  • Learn by doing, aided by just-in-time teaching. This means that people pick up the necessary skills just as they need them and put them into practice straight away.
  • Have the team learn together. This can be done by paired working and mentoring relationships.
  • Use best practice from the beginning. This maximises the benefit of applying RAP techniques, which become harder to implement down the line.

When choosing our first RAP project, consider that:

  • RAP can be used for producing tables, plots, models and more!
  • RAP is beneficial to official statistics and internal analyses alike.
  • RAP provides significant quality improvements for both repeated and ad hoc analyses.
  • RAP is designed for quantitative analysis. Whilst the pillars are also important for qualitative analysis, the practices are likely to differ.
  • RAP is easiest to implement when data sources, processes and outputs are stable. However, a well constructed RAP makes unstable environments easier to deal with. For example, when code is modular, fewer alterations are needed when inputs or outputs change.
  • RAP can provide the biggest benefits when projects are risky or time consuming.
  • RAP capability building takes time, and our first RAP project may take more time than expected. However, in the longer term RAP can provide great productivity improvements and subsequent RAPs should be quicker and easier than traditional methods of analysis. This is true whether rerunning similar analysis on new data, or creating new analysis. For example, good version control improves collaboration and open sourcing allows code to be shared and reused.

A successful transition to RAP will be aided by:

  • Commitment from managers and team members
  • Starting off with a base level of technical understanding – the minimum is basic skills in our programming language of choice.
  • Having the right tools in place.
  • Allocating time for the team to contribute, outside of their other responsibilities.
  • Having a plan for the new pipeline to transition to business as usual.

title: Blockers to a successful RAP
body:
Every RAP project is unique, but they can often face similar barriers to success. One common blocker to RAP is access to technology. The RAP Champions network set out that a RAP must be built using version control and open-source software, preferably Git and R or python. However, there are some government analysts that don’t have access to Git, R, and python. In this situation, we may need to request access from our IT and security departments. We can get help writing a business case by contacting analysts who have done this before or the Analysis Function RAP team. Even before you have access to the recommended technology, you can still get the benefits of other RAP components, for example peer review and good documentation.

Another possible blocker to delivering a successful RAP is traditional project management.

title: New Component Title
body: The use of other elements of RAP should be proportionate to the risk and complexity of our analysis. Once we have assessed the risk level of our analysis, we can use the Duck Book’s Code Quality Assurance Checklists to check what level of assurance is required. When assessing risk, there are several things we should consider:

_items.title: Quality risk - what is the chance of error in our analysis?
_items.body: We can address that risk with good peer review and version control and by embedding reproducibility in our analysis. Minimising manual steps means that errors are less likely to "randomly" appear.

_items.title: Risk of non-delivery - what are the consequences of not delivering the analysis?
_items.body: Once a team is capable in RAP, RAP is faster than traditional methods. This is especially true for repeated analysis, such as regularly released official statistics.

_items.title: Sustainability risk - what would happen if the team member who normally does the analysis left the team?
_items.body: Good RAP means good documentation and peer review, which can improve business continuity. However, for a RAP to be truly sustainable, the whole team must build RAP capability together.

_items.title: Reputational risk - can our stakeholders and the public trust your analysis?
_items.body: Open sourcing our analysis shows people we have nothing to hide. It promotes trust as our users can inspect the methods and documentation themselves. It encourages analysts to use best practices, however it is important that we do not cut corners, as that will also be visible.
